column1: Supplemental Table 6. Human food digestibility calculations for humans in the United States. Three foods (minimum) were selected from each dietary source category provided by Nakamaru et al. (1982). Stoichiometric measurements were recorded for each food (located by entering each food’s NDB# [Nutrient databank identifier] into the NDB search field at http://www.nal.usda.gov/fnic/foodcomp/search/). Digest [C] and Digest [N] are calculated using the formulas below. Mean [C] and [N] are calculated for each source category and weighed according to the weighting factors; in parentheses next to each dietary source category (Nakamaru et al. 1982). Weight [C] and [N] (and 1 SD) represent the estimated weighted [C] and [N] for human food in the United States. These parameters are fixed and used to estimate proportional dietary source contributions in all models that use such parameters. Data also published as on-line material in Hopkins and Ferguson (2011; in Press).
Units = gm X/100 gm wet weight

column2: Factors for calculating macronutrient dry weight (Robbins 1993)
Protein N = Protein (% dry weight) x 0.16
Protein C = Protein (% dry weight) x 0.52
Lipid C = Lipid (% dry weight) x 0.75
Carbohydrate C = Carbohydrate (% dry weight) x 0.45
Assume 100% digestibility for all sources for Lipid C and Carbohydrate C
Assume 100% protein digestibility for meat foods and 90% for plant foods (Koch and Phillips 2002)
Digest Protein C (terrestrial meat, fish/seafood, milk/cheese, eggs) = Protein C x 1.0
Digest Protein C (legumes/nuts, cereals, potatoes, vegetables, and fruits) = Protein C x 9.0
Digest [C] = Digest Protein C + Lipid C + Carbo C
Digest [N] (terrestrial meat, fish/seafood, milk/cheese, eggs) = Protein N x 1.0
Digest [N] (legumes/nuts, cereals, potatoes, vegetables, fruits) = Protein N x 9.0
Weight [C] & [N] = mean Total Digest [C] and Digest [N] for each group x group weight
Koch, P. L., and D. L. Phillips. 2002. Incorporating concentration dependence in stable isotope mixing models: a reply to Robbins, Hilderbrand and Farley. Oecologia 133: 14–18.

Nakamura, K., Schoeller, D. A., Winkler F. J., and H. L. Schmidt. 1982. Geographical variations in the carbon isotope composition of the diet and hair in contemporary man. Biomedical Mass Spectrometry 9: 390–394.
Robbins, C. T. 1993. Wildlife feeding and nutrition, 2nd edition. Academic Press, San Diego, California.
